title: PTD Today — Media

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award‑winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and connects themes of AI, data, and creativity. It frames the "unseen world of data centers" as the backdrop for how AI tools can empower artists and creative work.
bullets: Film ties AI and artistic creativity to the infrastructure of data centers.
Accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award‑winning podcast Where the Internet Lives.
Focus is on the "unseen world of data centers" that support digital experiences.
Produced/published by Google; no transcript available in the provided content.
Uses hashtags emphasizing WhereTheInternetLives, AI, Data, and Creativity.
takeaways: If AI-driven creative workloads are highlighted, expect growing electricity demand — plan substation capacity and power resiliency for variable, high‑compute loads.
Data center support for creative AI argues for integrating renewables and storage to manage peak/elastic demand and reduce operating carbon intensity.
Procurement and lifecycle planning should account for compute hardware needs tied to AI (implications for critical minerals and spares supply).
Public storytelling about data centers can influence community acceptance and permitting — communications teams should highlight benefits and mitigation measures.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno of Google Cloud explains that traditional networking and load balancing are ill-suited for AI inference and that AI-aware networking is required to optimize GPU-backed models. Google Cloud’s approach—using the GKE Inference Gateway, AI-aware load balancing, prefix/body-based routing, and network-level service extensions for guardrails—aims to reduce latency, avoid cold starts, and maximize GPU utilization while enforcing security and policy at the edge.
bullets: Uses inference-specific metrics (KV cache utilization, queue depth) to identify least-loaded replicas instead of relying on CPU metrics.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the load balancer reuse prefill computations to reduce repeated GPU work and latency.
Body-based routing and LoRA adapter awareness enable routing to the correct model/replica based on request content.
Service Extensions let API management and AI guardrails run in the network path to sanitize prompts/responses before hitting GPUs.
Expected outcomes: fewer cold starts, higher GPU saturation, lower TCO, and faster developer velocity via unified APIs.
takeaways: Power & capacity planning: Better GPU saturation reduces wasted cycles and evens out power draw, impacting peak provisioning and cooling needs.
Demand spikes & latency: Intelligent routing and cache reuse lower peak instantaneous load and latency—helpful for managing short-term demand on site electrical systems.
Energy/cost savings: Network-level guardrails that drop invalid requests before GPU execution can materially reduce compute and energy costs.
Operational complexity: Centralized AI-aware routing and service extensions can simplify network topology and orchestration for multi-model deployments.
Procurement & sizing: Improved utilization metrics should influence future GPU procurement and rack power density decisions by revealing true effective load.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this is a short visual showcase of the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with NVIDIA RTX enabled and DLSS 4 Multi Frame Generation. The clip promotes #RTXOn visuals and credits creator @DigitalDreamsyt; no transcript is provided.
bullets: No transcript available in the provided content.
Title: Where Winds Meet — an open-world martial arts RPG.
Highlights NVIDIA features: DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation and #RTXOn.
Video credited to DigitalDreamsyt.
Published by NVIDIA GeForce on 2026-01-14.
takeaways: Modern RTX and DLSS features imply continued demand for high-performance GPUs—plan capacity, power delivery, and cooling for bursts of graphics/AI compute.
GPU-accelerated gaming and visual workloads can create variable peak loads; consider energy storage or demand-management strategies to smooth grid impact.
Features that change rendering approaches (like DLSS/MFG) can alter workload efficiency and power profiles—test real-world power/thermal behavior before scaling.
Large-scale adoption of advanced GPUs reinforces exposure to critical-minerals and semiconductor supply-chain risk when planning procurement and refresh cycles.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova stresses the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and deciding on next steps to preserve steam plant reliability. The short video points viewers to GE Vernova resources for rotor end-of-life guidance and frames rotor lifecycle management as central to plant performance.
bullets: Topic: assessing remaining life of steam turbine rotors.
Goal: help operators determine what to do next as rotors age.
Resource: directs viewers to GE Vernova's rotor EOL webpage.
Framing: rotor lifecycle management positioned as core to steam plant reliability.
Context: part of GE Vernova’s broader energy and decarbonization messaging.
takeaways: Prioritize rotor life assessments to reduce risk of unplanned outages and preserve grid or facility reliability.
Incorporate rotor end-of-life timing into maintenance, outage scheduling, and capital planning for power assets or data center backup plants.
Engage OEMs or specialist teams (e.g., GE Vernova) early for inspection, refurbishment, or replacement options and cost/time estimates.
Treat rotor lifecycle decisions as part of broader asset management and decarbonization plans to maintain performance while planning upgrades.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this KPMG podcast episode discusses current trends reshaping the luxury goods market in Poland and globally — including a shift toward experiences over ownership, growing ESG expectations, the rise of "affordable luxury," personalization, and the role of AI and craftsmanship in the future. KPMG experts Andrzej Marczak and Tomasz Wiśniewski also highlight market structure (top 2% of customers account for ~40% of sales), Poland's growing but fragmented luxury scene, and opportunities in luxury tourism, hotels and the art market.
bullets: Global trends: "luxury fatigue," experience-first consumption, and Gen Z preference for experiences over possessions.
Concentration of value: ~2% of the wealthiest customers drive about 40% of the luxury market.
ESG and responsible luxury rising — eco-leathers, certifications and sustainability claims matter.
Poland: growing but fragmented luxury market with opportunities in hotels, spas, Baltic tourism and contemporary art.
Future drivers include personalization, AI-enabled services, artisanal craftsmanship and branded experiences through hospitality and film.
takeaways: Rising luxury tourism and premium hotels in Poland imply localized increases in electricity demand and the need for resilient backup power at hospitality sites.
Greater use of AI and personalized digital experiences will increase demand for compute and low-latency services — plan capacity for data centers and edge compute serving luxury brands.

ESG certification and responsible sourcing trends favor investments in renewables and on-site storage for hospitality and retail sites, plus transparent supply chains that may increase demand for critical minerals tracking.
High-end customer expectations for uninterrupted, premium experiences raise requirements for power quality, redundancy and rapid recovery strategies in retail, hotel and event locations.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this short video emphasizes that PJM Interconnection has prioritized reliable electricity since 1927. It aims to explain how PJM works to make sure power is available when customers need it.
bullets: PJM Interconnection has made reliability its top priority since 1927.
Video is an overview of how PJM works to ensure electricity availability.
No transcript is available; summary is based solely on the brief description provided.
Intended as an educational piece about PJM's reliability focus rather than a technical deep dive.
takeaways: Treat PJM's longstanding reliability focus as a prompt to prioritize resilience measures (redundant feeds, UPS, onsite generation) for critical facilities.
Monitor PJM communications and reliability alerts to inform operational and outage-response planning for data centers and substations.
When planning renewables or storage projects, align deployment and operational strategies with the grid operator’s reliability priorities to support stable integration.
Incorporate supply-chain considerations for critical minerals when sizing and specifying long-duration storage or backup power systems to ensure long-term availability.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy frames grid modernization as a balance of reliability, flexibility and efficiency while expanding capacity for the energy transition. The company highlights power grid technologies with digital capabilities at the core to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance across the network.
bullets: Power systems must scale capacity while preserving reliability, flexibility and efficiency.
Hitachi Energy positions digital technologies as central to grid modernization.
Digital solutions are presented to improve stability, reduce downtime and optimize performance.
Modernization supports integration of renewables and storage to meet transition goals.
Resource link provided for more details from the vendor.
takeaways: Prioritize digital grid platforms to enhance stability and minimize outages.
Adopt digital-enabled predictive maintenance to reduce downtime and operating costs.
Design capacity upgrades with flexibility to integrate renewables and storage without sacrificing reliability.
Data center operators should engage with grid modernization efforts to secure power quality and resilience.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy highlights that resilient industries rely on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. The company works with customers and partners to build smarter systems that improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus on energy efficiency as a foundation for industrial resilience.
Process optimization reduces waste and improves operational output.
Digital integration enables smarter, data-driven system management.
Partnerships with technology providers help deliver system-level solutions.
Goals: higher productivity, greater reliability, and improved sustainability.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency measures to enhance resilience and lower operating cost.
Adopt digital tools (monitoring, analytics) to optimize processes and enable predictive maintenance.
Seek technology partners for integrated solutions rather than piecemeal upgrades.
Align productivity and reliability improvements with sustainability targets to maximize business value.
